official-title.#text:
To ensure that the Federal Aviation
		  Administration advances the safety of small airplanes, and the continued
		  development of the general aviation industry, and for other
		  purposes.

action-desc.#text:
Reported with an amendment, committed to the Committee of
		  the Whole House on the State of the Union, and ordered to be
		  printed

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

A healthy small aircraft
			 industry is integral to economic growth and to maintaining an effective
			 transportation infrastructure for communities and nations around the
			 world.
Small aircraft comprise nearly 90 percent of

General aviation provides
			 for the cultivation of a workforce of engineers, manufacturing and maintenance
			 professionals, and pilots, who secure the Nation’s economic success and
			 defense.

General aviation
			 contributes to well-paying manufacturing and technology jobs in the United
			 States, and these products are exported in great numbers, providing a positive
			 trade balance.

Technology developed and
			 proven in general aviation aids in the success and safety of all sectors of
			 aviation and scientific competence.

The average small
			 airplane in the United States is now 40 years old and the regulatory barriers
			 to bringing new designs to market are resulting in a lack of innovation and
			 investment in small airplane design.

Over the past decade, the
			 United States has typically lost 10,000 active private pilots per year,
			 partially due to a lack of cost-effective, new small airplanes.

General aviation safety
			 can be improved by modernizing and revamping the regulations for this sector to
			 clear the path for technology adoption and cost-effective means to retrofit the
			 existing fleet with new safety technologies.

header.#text:
FAA safety and
			 regulatory improvements for general aviation

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall advance the safety and continued development of small airplanes by reorganizing the certification requirements applicable to small airplanes to streamline the approval of safety advancements.

text.#text: The

header.#text:
Establishment of FAA
			 safety and regulatory improvements for general aviation

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall issue a final rule based on the FAA’s Part 23
			 Reorganization Aviation Rulemaking Committee (established in August 2011) by
			 December 31, 2015. The final rule shall meet the following objectives of the
			 Part 23 Committee:

text.#text: The

Create a regulatory
			 regime for small airplanes that will improve safety and decrease certification
			 costs.

Set broad, outcome-driven
			 safety objectives that will spur innovation and technology adoption.
Replace current, prescriptive requirements contained in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: -accepted consensus standards to clarify how the part 23 safety objectives may be met by specific designs and technologies.

text.#text: Use

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall use acceptable consensus-based
			 standards whenever possible in the spirit of the

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, while continuing traditional
			 methods for meeting part 23.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
National Technology Transfer
			 and Advancement Act of 1996
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act of 1996

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall lead the effort to improve
			 general aviation safety by working with leading aviation regulators to assist
			 them in adopting a complementary regulatory approach for small
			 airplanes.

text.#text: The

In this Act, the following definitions
			 apply:

quote.#tail:
means
			 the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.

text.#text: The term

quote.#tail:
means
			 standards developed by voluntary organizations which plan, develop, establish,
			 or coordinate voluntary standards using agreed-upon procedures, both domestic
			 and international. These standards include provisions requiring that owners of
			 relevant intellectual property agree to make that intellectual property
			 available on a nondiscriminatory, royalty-free or reasonable-royalty basis to
			 all interested parties. These bodies have the attributes of openness, balance
			 of interest, due process, an appeals process, and consensus.

text.#text: The term

The
			 term

quote.#tail:
means all
			 aviation activities other than scheduled commercial airline operations and
			 military aviation.

text.#text: The term

quote.#tail:
means part 23 of title 14,
			 Code of Federal Regulations.

text.#text: The term
The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: type certificated airplanes that meet the parameters of part 23 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
